Name: Documentation establishing proof of identity and proof of residency for a New York city identity card.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to documentation establishing proof of identity and proof of residency for a New York city identity card.

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee

Attachments.Name: Minutes of the Stated Meeting - October 27, 2022

Summary: This bill would amend Section 3-115 of the Administrative Code to add documentation and verifications to the list of acceptable documents for proof of identity needed to apply for an IDNYC card. The bill includes documents issued by federal immigration authorities, electronic verification through the department of correction, and a released offender verification card. This bill would also amend the documents accepted for proof of residency to include written verification from emergency housing deemed appropriate by the agency.

\ul\v0\par
Be it enacted by the Council as follows:\ulnone\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\qj\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Section 1. Subdivision d of section 3-115 of the administrative code of the city of New York, as added by local law number 35 for the year 2014, is amended to read as follows:\par
d. New York city identity card eligibility. In order to obtain a New York city identity card an applicant must establish proof of identity and proof of residency within the city as follows:\par
(1) Proof of identity. In order to establish identity, an applicant shall be required to produce one or more of the following documents \ul or verifications\ulnone :\par
(i) a U.S. or foreign passport;\par
(ii) a U.S. state driver\rquote s license;\par
(iii) a U.S. state identification card;\par
(iv) a U.S. permanent resident card;\par
(v) a consular identification card;\par
(vi) a photo identification card with name, address, date of birth, and expiration date issued by another country to its citizens or nationals as an alternative to a passport for re-entry to the issuing country;\par
(vii) a certified copy of U.S. or foreign birth certificate;\par
(viii) a Social Security card;\par
(ix) a national identification card with photo, name, address, date of birth, and expiration date;\par
(x) a foreign driver\rquote s license;\par
(xi) a U.S. or foreign military identification card;\par
(xii) a current visa issued by a government agency;\par
(xiii) a U.S. individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN) authorization letter;\par
(xiv) an electronic benefit transfer (EBT) card; [or]\par
(xv) \ul U.S. department of homeland security forms I-385 (alien booking record), I-862 (notice to appear), I-220A (order to release on recognizance), or I-220B (order of supervision);\par
(xvi) electronic verification through the department of correction incarcerated individual lookup system; \par
(xvii) a released offender identification card issued by the New York state department of corrections and community renewal; or\par
(xviii)\ulnone  any other documentation that the administering agency deems acceptable. The administering agency may by rule determine the weight to be given to each type of document \ul or verification\ulnone  provided in this paragraph, and require that an applicant produce more than one document to establish identity.\par
(2) Proof of residency. In order to establish residency, an applicant shall be required to produce one or more of the following items each of which must show the applicant's name and residential address located within the city and must be dated no more than sixty days prior to the date such document is presented, except as otherwise indicated in this paragraph:\par
(i) a utility bill;\par
(ii) a current residential property lease;\par
(iii) a local property tax statement dated within one year of the date it is submitted;\par
(iv) a local real property mortgage payment receipt;\par
(v) a bank account statement;\par
(vi) proof that the applicant has a minor child currently enrolled in a school located within the city;\par
(vii) an employment pay stub;\par
(viii) a jury summons or court order issued by a federal or state court;\par
(ix) a federal or state income tax or refund statement dated within one year of the date it is submitted;\par
(x) an insurance bill (homeowner, renter, health, life, or automobile insurance);\par
(xi) written verification issued by a homeless shelter\ul , including emergency housing deemed appropriate by the administering agency,\ulnone  that receives city funding confirming at least fifteen days residency;\par
(xii) written verification issued by a hospital, health clinic or social services agency located within the city of New York confirming at least fifteen days residency; or\par
(xiii) Any other documentation that the administering agency deems acceptable.\par
(xiv) The administering agency may by rule determine the weight to be given to each type of document provided in this paragraph, and require that an applicant produce more than one document to establish residency. The administering agency shall by rule create alternative methods by which individuals who are homeless can establish residency in the city notwithstanding the lack of fixed address.\par
\'a7 2. This local law takes effect 120 days after it becomes law.\par
\pard\ltrpar\qj\fs18\par
